tail: NGU. The one who thinks to know a lot, does not know anything. 2932. Ajifunzaye haachi kujua. ZAW, p.xi. One who studies goes on learning. No learning is a waste of effort - Zaw.
FSM 9. A person who is here in the world has not yet been totally created. A person goes on learning until death. A person is being formed [createdl as long as that person lives.

quote: Asiyejua kitu, hawezi kujua thamani yake.
tail: KB 26. A person who does not know an object cannot know its value.

SAM 4.21. People who do not see by themselves, do not see [even] when it is shown to them. This is said of an intelligent adult who does not see the difference between good and evil, between justice and injustice, between politeness and rudeness - SAM. We must know ourselves before we can understand others. Cf. 2056.
JKP. Whoever has no knowledge, let that person be taught and learn and thus follow [the rules].
F 5.41. One who does not ask a question learns nothing. Cf. 2968.
EM 25.10. Business is arithmetic. Arithmetic is an essential tool in business. Hit and miss business is like a journey undertaken in the wilderness where there are no paths - EM. Cf. 973.

quote: Cha mkufunzi mwanafunzi hali na akila hufa:  cha mwanafunzi mkufunzi hula na akila hafi.
person: KA. This saying was used in the days of capitalism
tail: T 49; MA 92. A student does not eat [the food] of the teacher, and if a student does eat, that student will die; but if the teacher eats [the food] of the student, the teacher does not die. Used if a junior does not respect his seniors - KA. This saying was used in the days of capitalism, when pupils used to send presents such as eggs to their teachers - EM. Mkufuu or mwalimu, teacher. Mwanafuu or mwanafunzi, a student.

quote: Chakula kilicho mbali usipokipata, unaweza  kupata kwa wengine.
tail: KB 38. Food out of reach, you can get it from others. By learning, knowledge.
NGU; JKP. A cerificate is a surety. Rank is a trust - JKP. Cheo, rank, degree, status, certificate.

EM 45.8. A person's ceiling is the head. In many places the ceiling of the house is used as a store. A person collects a lot of ideas and preserves them in the head until called upon to use them - EM. Sifa: honor, quality. Is sometimes used instead of dari.
NGU. A person's value is the head.

quote: Elimu bila amali, kama  nta bila asali.
tail: RSP 82. Knowledge without practice is like wax without honey.
KS mtalaa. Learning without practice is lost. Mtalaa, lessons, practice - KS. Mtala, mtaala, practice - Krapf.
EM 53.1. Education has no end. One is never too old to learn.
JKP. Knowledge is the arbiter. "No judge or umpire can decide without knowledge"÷ - JKP.
EM 54.5. Education is life, not books. You cannot learn all the things that matter in life from books.

quote: Elimu ndio mwanga uongozayo kila shani.
tail: T 110; SPK; SACL 714; MS 28 ilimu; AL, shani. Knowledge is the light that leads to everything wonderful. With intelligence one emerges from a difficult case - AL.
J bahari; EM 53. Learning is like an ocean.

quote: Elimu ni kama  bahari haina sahili.
tail: JKP. Knowledge is like an ocean without shores.

quote: Elimu ni kama bahari, haina kuta wala dari.
tail: SPK. Science is like an ocean, it has neither walls nor a roof. The pursuit of learning is like a voyage for life: it will never end against a wall nor can the spirit be stopped when rising up - SPK.

quote: Elimu ni mali ambayo adui hawezi kuiteka.
tail: EM 53.2. Education is a possession that no enemy can capture.
KA. Education cannot be stolen. Teka or chukua, twaa, to take.
RSP 41. Knowledge is like a lamp, it will shine everywhere.
JKP. Search for knowledge [even] in China, whenever you need it.
JKP. The advantage of knowing is following. "It is useful to know people's views and habits beforehand. So one can avoid giving offenses: good public relations" - JKP.

quote: Fimbo umpigayo mtoto yamfikia kwa ngozi,  haifikii tabia yake mbaya.
tail: AL 442. The stick you beat the child with reaches its body, it does not reach its bad character. Physical punishment is most of the time inadequate - AL.
MARA 2. A fool learns by his troubles. It is because the fool did not listen to advice.
EM g2. Light is the enemy of darkness. Ukweli utawapeni uhuru, the truth will set you free. Cf. 849, 3150.
AL 428. A child should not be afraid of dew. Unpleasant things are character-forming.
NGU. Knowledge/wisdom is independent of age and color. All can acquire knowledge.
KS mswaki. These sums are [easy like] a toothbrush. Said by students. Easy to make. Mswaki, a toothbrush made from a small tree-root.

quote: Kama kungwi  wandazi nipe changu kitumbua.
tail: FSM 61. If I am a pastry teacher, give me a rice-fritter. When a student does not follow the rules that are taught, the teacher will use this proverb. It's a way of telling the student that a fault was made. It could also be used by the teacher to tell the student that a reward should be given to the teacher, which might be of more common usage.
NGU; J kunga. Work is no good unless you have been taught the art. Kunga, secret, trick, device; private instruction.
AL 438; AL pota. A youth is like a twisted twig. Should be educated while young.

quote: Kila mnyama hufundishwa na mizungu yake.
tail: AL mzungu. Every animal is taught by its instincts. Mizungu, instructions given during puberty or initiation.
NGU. Learning is imitating.

quote: Kujua kidogo hatari kutojua kabisa usiku wa  manane.
tail: NGU. The danger in knowing a little is knowing nothing at midnight. Not knowing enough when needed. Usiku wa manane, midnight

AL 451. In drying the palm nuts, the stone has dried also. The palm nuts are put on a stone or rock to dry, but also the stone on which the nuts were crushed is drying. Too many loveless admonitions disturb the child - AL.

quote: Kula nyama ya mwalimu ni kula sumu.
tail: JKP. To eat the meat of scholars is eating poison. Slandering a teacher is like eating poison. "Scholars, i.e. Islamic scholars, who teach the Koran, are holy men who must not be harmed" - JKP. Kula nyama ya mtu, to eat meat of somebody is an idiom meaning slandering a person's name. Cf. 2939.
JKP. The ability to read does not make a secretary. More is needed to be a good secretary.
MARA 34; MEM 108; ZAW. Asking questions is not ignorance.
FSM 144. A questioner has knowledge. A student who asks questions learns more than one who does not; a wise person questions before beginning an enterprise.
HM. Degrade yourself in order to know. Cf. 2937.
SPK. Life is the best teacher.
KB 169. First there is darkness, then there is cleverness. An inexperienced person can become clever.
NGU. An old dog does not learn new tricks.
SPK. Teach the ignorant, open [the door of knowledge] that is closed.

quote: Mkono kufunua usikie, mkono kufungwa  hukusikia.
tail: AL 389. Understand the meaning of the open hand while you did not understand the meaning of the closed hand [fist]. One who is eager to learn will grasp any occasion. An open hand explains, but a closed hand does not.
AL 424. The hand that raises the child rules the world. Education forms the child's future.

quote: Mpumbavu alienda porini, akaokota tembo,  akasahau njia yake.
tail: AL 426. The fool went into the forest, picked up an elephant, and forgot the way back. It is not enough to bear children, one must also educate them - AL.

quote: Mtaka maarifa huwa rafiki wenye maarifa.
tail: MA 354. One who is after knowledge befriends people with knowledge.

quote: Mto ulikunjama, sababu ulikosa mtu wa  kuungoza.
tail: AL 437. The river meanders, because it did not have a guide. Poor education ends up with a good-for-nothing person.
NGU. A child starts crawling and that's how it may stand up.

quote: Mtoto yatima hawezi kutanda wavu mrefu.
tail: AL 425. An orphan is not able to set a long net [to catch game]. Without education a child is not ready for life.
RSP 82. A scholar does not have hardship.

F 34.144; T 370; A 73; V 135; KB 210. A chick is not taught how to scratch up the ground for food. Some things come naturally. Kifaranga,or mwana wa kuku. a chick Tony Hillerman writes about a "belagana", a busybody:"His mother would have called her in Navajo, 'One who tells sheep which weed to eat'." Skinwalkers, p.95 (N.Y.: Harper Perennial Library, 1988). Cf. 2980.
ED 53; JK 131. The young of a snake is not taught to bite.
F 35.162; FSM 160. One who has eyes is not told to look. Be alert, use all your gifts.
FSM 157. One who has a mouth gets no help in speaking. Someone who is able to do a job is not helped, but on the other hand, we should help those who cannot help themselves.
SPK. When the moon appears the stars disappear. The moon is the symbol of nobility and scholarship - SPK.
SPK. The meat of scholars is poison. If you harm a scholar you will die. If you refuse to feed a scholar, the food that he ought to have received will be poisonous - SPK.

quote: 2981c. O! Akili na elimu zitakapo kukutana.
tail: SPK. Oh! intelligence and knowledge when they meet!

quote: Popo huning'iniza kichwa chini aone wafanyao  ndege wengine.
tail: EM 29.20. The bat hangs with its head down watching the actions of other birds. It is better to observe or investigate a matter silently than ostentatiously to make a lot of noise about it - EM.
REK. Donkeys that don't know each other first sniff each other.
REK. The soul is a stranger. Is difficult to know.
AL 423. In a field where peanuts were planted, there is no lack of young sprouts [after the harvest]. A good education leaves its marks.
SPK. Never stop studying so you may acquire wisdom.
Mlezi Oct-Nov. 1982, p.3. Walk around and see for yourself, don't wait to be told. Cf. 3177.

quote: Ujualo ni hazina ya maisha yako.
tail: NGU. What you know is a treasure of your life.

quote: Ujuzi bila vitendo ni ujinga, sio mwendo.
tail: REK. Knowledge without deeds is stupidity, it's not a life.
NGU. Knowledge never gets old. Ujuzi, knowledge, wisdom, sagacity, practical experience.
NGU. Knowledge is strength

quote: Ukitaka kujifunza, mwishowe utashinda,  ukichoka hupotea.
tail: JKP. If you want to learn something you will succeed in the end, but if you give up, you will lose.
MARA 69. If you know this [side], that [side] you do not [necessarily] know. One cannot know everything: there is always more to learn. There is always someone who knows more about it.
NGU; AL 1577;F 26.11. What beats you is what teaches you. The misfortune that strikes you teaches you. Ukupigao + ukufunzao, the u and o refer to the noun msiba (misfortune), that is understood.
AL 422. The night does not bring forth a comely child. Upbringing and education produces a child you can show off.

person: JK. If you want to learn the trade properly
tail: JK 141. Go fishing with a fisherman who loves fishes - JK. If you want to learn the trade properly, study the ways of someone who loves it - JK.
AL 392. Those European articles don't end ignorance. One always has to learn more, even from strangers.
NGU. You know where you came from.
EM. Time is a tutor. A person may not understand something the first time. But after living with it for a sufficient time, one may understand it - EM.
JK 134. Two learned men will learn from each other. Hufundana or hufundishana.

quote: 2999a. Watafutao elimu wako njiani kwa mungu.
tail: SPK. The seekers of knowledge are on the path of God.
EM y4. Things have happened to a person for knowing too much. To show off one's knowledge may get one into trouble. So, it is better to be humble - EM.
